review_title: The one thing relevant in "The Emoji Movie" is it's failure, let's examine the industrial accident...
review_detailed_main:
In my "Top Gun" review, I said there was nothing wrong with the 'commercial' look of the film since the product placement is the whole setting. I sarcastically added: 'except for the emoji movie'. To be fair, I hadn't seen the movie. Now, I did. Do I withdraw my statement? Nope.

But let's face it, criticizing "The Emoji Movie" would be like Homer Simpson repetitively hitting the Krusty burglar with that kid crying "stop it, stop it, he's already dead". No need to punch the cadaver or shoot the ambulance as French say, "The Emoji Movie" achieve one milestone by becoming the first film to win the Worst Picture Razzie... it did so brilliantly that commentators went pretty creative on it (one remembers the Rotten Tomatoes consensus). I'll try to be more constructive.

Let's examine the film. First, it's not the 'product placement' that is problematic, besides "Top Gun", you have many quality films that couldn't do without brandname-dropping ("The Social Network", "Cast Away"...). The real insult is that the writers took our 'wow' for granted just because we're having familiar everyday technology on the big screen. Some bits like the Firewall or the Dropbox were okay but did we need that lengthy dancing app sequence? Couldn't have they come up with something more imaginative with at least ONE social network?

Some would argue that the real mistake was to make a bland cardboard character out of the young smartphone owner... and that predictable crush no one could care about. I think it's downright impossible to make a deep soul connection between emojis and people à la "Inside Out" (which it obviously ripped off). It's tough enough to make emojis as relatable as humans but humans are bound to appear as predictable and boring as emojis if they're defined by them. Now, would have the film worked better if it was just about Emojis? You know, like the Smurfs... but how do you make an Emoji movie without their main users?

Gosh, must have been one hell of a brainstorming session in that conference room!

Now, supposing humans are relegated to supporting players (after all, it did work for the Lego movie) but then how about the Emoji characters? You have a 'Meh' emoji who refuses to be defined by one expression: we got it: MISFIT. You have Jailbreak as the female who doesn't want to be 'categorized' and rejects love, we got it: GIRL POWER. Hi-5 is the comical sidekick, and Patrick Stewart is the prestigious cameo, voicing Poo. And you know what? That's not even the problem.

Have a respectable actor voice a poo, and it's an average gag at best. Have him say only poo-related jokes, it kills, annihilates and exterminates the fun. Humor is a matter of contrast, so let's just have a poo behaving like a respectable citizen (did I just write that?) Having the Big Bad as a Smiley was an interesting twist... although nothing new (cough *Joker*). Now, don't get me start on 'Meh' parents, the most tired joke of the film, and the responsible for a puzzlement I never thought I'd have: do emojis reproduce? Do 'Meh's go only with 'Meh's? Are emojis racist? Do a crying and a happy one made a happy tears one?

Like another film I reviewed recently, "The Emoji Movie" is a film that the more it makes sense, the less it does. The premise is ludicrous though it had potential, the treatment was predictable but exploiting many overused tropes from better movies, the product placements were superficial, the human world didn't make us care and ultimately, it's hard to imagine Emojis as living creatures.

Finally, I remembered the way I use my own emojis: my favorite are the Thumbs Up when I want to save myself writing two lines of approval, the kissing heart when I receive pictures of babies... which makes me realize that I hate when I get only emojis as answers. Let's be honest, emojis are semantic loopholes, products of our intellectual laziness and yet the film portrays them as a pillar of the new-age communication. I wouldn't say no one wants to watch a movie to remember how lobotomized we are by these little creatures... but not one that gives a noble dimension to their existence.

Now, there's a hidden relevance in the film, something that could have elevated it to the level of social comment, had it dared to have an edge, to end with a moral twist where the boy would win the girl's heart by just talking to her... how about having that message communicated to the climax 'talk to her' or something like that... that the film obviously makes the emojis the alpha and omega of the life of a teenager could only foreshadow its failure. Not to say that there aren't good moments, the animation can please the kiddies on a mindless level, although the graphics might be too overstimulating.

Still, I'm glad the film was made because if cinema needs masterpieces, it also needs a few occasional big stinks. Movies like "Cats" or "Batman and Robin". Movies that reveal how far Hollywood marketing can go in its faith on our mediocrity and how low it can sink for the sake of cash-making flashy idiocy.

Cinema needs movies that make audience say "enough is enough', movies that show that even the lousiest gimmicks are supposed to serve a plot, that kids aren't just dim-witted consumers who'd grab anything just because it's got pretty nice colors.

There's a limit to how far you can push the me-toos (I mean the marketing strategy) to emulate dinosaurs, while reality put you back to the state of La Fontaine's frog that wished to be as big as an Ox and so she started puffing herself out and kept doing it more and more. What happened to her is the perfect metaphor for "The Emoji Movie" ultimate fate.

I think the Candy Crush segment was probably the most insulting. I mean, they literally explain the rules of the game, just so you know how to play when you hopefully download it after the film is over.

review_title: Light and cheesy - not as awful as some might say, but not stellar.
review_detailed_main:
I've noticed this movie is getting a lot of hate ratings, and I wonder how many of the people that have rated it 1 have actually seen the movie. I have seen some movies that are worth rating a 1 before, but The Emoji Movie isn't quite that bad. This was the perfect movie for my 11 year old son, as he LOVED It! I was mildly amused. The movie wasn't awful, and it wasn't great.

The movie is about a "meh" emoticon that gets sent (by the user) while making a different face. Apparently, it is unheard of to make the wrong face, so that gets him into a lot of trouble. He befriends an emoticon that used to be popular, but is hardly ever used now, and they seek out a emoticon defector/hacker to help Gene (Meh), become the meh he thinks he is supposed to be. I felt the movie had a good message about being yourself, although the character's aren't given much depth in the film.

If you are considering taking your kids to this because you want something to do, but are unsure because of your reviews, you could take a chance on it. If you are broke and don't go to the movies very often, however, wait for video or streaming. Overall, it is a light, cheesy watch if there isn't anything else to see with the kids.

review_title: The Emoji Movie is a shameless, ninety minute commercial with nothing to be proud of. SHAME ON YOU SONY!
review_detailed_main:
Ever since The Lego Movie was made, I've taken it upon myself to be open to more ideas that sound like cash grabs, but could also be more. The Lego Movie sounded like a giant commercial for the toy company. Instead, it was smart tribute to the creativity it inspires and was very funny. That has made me realize that out of everything, storytelling can allow anything to be engaging if people can emotionally connect with it enough. If people could find that connection with a bunch of toys and bricks, whose to say that the same thing could be found with emojis?

Most people with smartphones have used an emoji at some point. I myself like the ones that either engage laughter or show off that I'm trying to convey something smooth. While I have no problem using it every once and a while, I dislike it when it becomes the prominent way of communication. I haven't asked any teenagers about that, but I'm sure that most of them still need text to order specific food or to tell their parents that their out until midnight. I like the think that all teens are smart, but The Emoji Movie makes them an unsalable group.

In the smartphone of high schooler Alex (played by Jake T. Austin), is where all the emojis live where they live and work a part of the texting app. Meh emojis Mel (played by Steven Wright) and Mary (played by Jennifer Coolidge) are about their see their son Gene (played by T.J. Miller) go off to be used in his first text. Gene seems to have the ability to show other expressions and that happens when his text goes wrong. The leader of the emojis Smiler (played by Maya Rudolph) talks with other emojis like the Devil Emoji (played by Sean Hayes), dancer emoji (played by Sofia Vergara) and Poop emoji (played by Patrick Stewart) about what to do.

When Gene gets word that he is likely to be deleted, he escapes with the hand emoji, HI-5 (played by James Cordon). Upon leaving the texting app, he finds a jailbreak emoji (played by Anna Faris) who tells him that if they can get to the Icloud, then his source code can be fixed. From there, they go through several apps including Candy Crush, Instagram, Just Dance, and more while everybody learns about being themselves...or something like that.

Sony pictures should be ashamed. The Emoji Movie has to be one of the most obvious product plug movies ever made. I thought The Internship (the movie about Google) was bad, but this sets a new record. Not only do the story rip off Wreck it Ralph, Inside Out and The Lego Movie, but several times, the plot just stops to make another advertisement. If anything, I felt like I just sat through an introduction for a cult; a cult that clearly does not understand how teenagers, computers, programs, apps, games, and emotional storytelling work.

Even for it's obnoxious tie ins, how are the characters? As hard as the majority of these actors try, this script does everything to suck out anything funny or interesting. This is more then a bad movie; this is a black mark on a resume that is likely to hurt every single person involved. I cannot remember anytime that I laughed, nor even heard a chuckle from the kids in my theater. I can only imagine that the parents that took their kids to this were punishing them. I wouldn't have been that cruel to my own. This is a movie that simply appeals to no one (it's too adult for kids and too stupid for the teenage audience they would have been the better targeted crowd).

Is the animation even worth noting? Even that suffers from the story. Because the majority of the emojis are necessarily bright for their use, this doesn't allow them to pop out. It's just a mess of pixilation and phone advertisements.

This kind of movie makes me mad that millions of dollars are spent making this garbage over original stories that aspiring artists are trying to pitch.

I'll give this one poop emojis out of five. This movie doesn't even deserve a formal ending, so I'll end it on this: Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony Shame on you Sony

It's literally a movie about Emojis. EMOJIS. What is the point of it?! It's a wreck it Ralph rip-off and doesn't deserve to even be in the same sentence as Dunkirk. Don't see this movie. Don't give it money. Kill it. Bury it. Go see Dunkirk or Baby Driver. Also apparently they might get enough money for a sequel? Let's not have that. Please? Those are my thoughts. Don't see this "film" if I can even call it that.

(Warning: Contains Minor Spoilers) One does not watch a film like The Emoji Movie expecting anything but corporate pandering from a company as vile as Sony. However the film somehow managed to be worst than my expectations. Considering I have seen both The Nut Job and Minions in theaters, saying The Emoji Movie is the worst animated film I have ever seen, and one of the worst films I have ever seen, shows that the true quality of this film. What's the plot? Gene the emoji wants to become "meh," as he is a malfunction. After destroying the emoji center, Smiler, who is simply annoying, wants to kill Gene. Gene finds a useless comic relief named Hi-Five, who leads him Jailbreak, a hacker emoji that has extremely forced character traits. You can assume that along the way there will be poop jokes, jokes that are so bad you don't even know they're jokes, bad outdated references, a void of likable characters and emotion (ironic for a film centered around emojis), forced feminism, a romance between meh and female meh that is focused on for around 20 minutes,and scenes, like the one centered in Just Dance, that are so blatantly awful and go on for so long, you will want to bludgeon yourself multiple times. Whenever you think the film can't get worse it does, and by the third act, my friends and I laughed so hard, since the ending was so nonsensical, pandering, and followed every cliché you've seen in other awful kids movies, like the ending dance sequence, except they are executed worse. One may say there are worse films than The Emoji Movie, and there probably are. And by that I mean there may be a few films worse than it. But the mentality behind this film, created from a greedy company that wants to create low-effort garbage to exploit a young audience while having the audacity to also make fun of that audience, as lazily as one could. This company pushes back reviews to allow films like this to do well, and says that the film isn't bad because it is made for a certain age group. This company has no purpose, other than to leech off of your money, and to continue releasing mass quantities of terrible films, like The Star, and potentially Peter Rabbit. review_title: What's with all the bad reviews??
review_detailed_main: We enjoyed watching this with the kids. My kids do love this movie and just keep watching it again and again. I'm shocked to learn it has so many awful reviews. I cannot tell how good or bad the director of the movie is. But as a regular viewer who has small kids I can say it is quite entertaining and has some good things for little kids to learn, e.g. the main character, Gene, never leaves his friends behind and treats other members of his little emoji world with kindness no matter where they are in their social hierarchy. There are some interesting parallels with the real world as well: Gene has to be "meh" just like his parents who are "real pros". But instead he has a special ability to express many feelings at once which is treated as a "malfunction". One real story I can recall was about a kid who was incredibly talented dancer but could not focus in class and was nearly diagnosed with ADHD. We force kids and people in general into some sort of boxes and if they don't fit we consider it a disorder, a "malfunction", something that is not cool and should be fixed. This animation movie teaches little kids to be themselves and freely express themselves. Old idea but good nonetheless. This is great. Whoever left extremely low ratings are probably sad people who cannot see anything good in life. Maybe the storyline wasn't great and the director wasn't good but there are good things about this anination and you cannot seriously be that displeased with just about everything.

review_title: It's not the worst movie ever, but I do agree with the general consensuses..
review_detailed_main:
The Emoji Movie is not the worst movie ever. Yes this movies has its limitations in a lot of places, and honestly, I can't think of another movie made blatantly based on the assumption, "KIDS WILL WATCH ANYTHING!" mentality but it's not the worst. I've heard people say, "It's just a kids movie! Were you really expecting a masterpiece out of an emoji?"

First off, animated movies have broken our expectations before. If you can make a masterpiece out of; a rat who wants to be a chef (Ratatouille), a penguin who can surf (Surf's up), oh and A PANDA WHO WANTS TO DO MARTIAL ARTS (Kung Fu Panda), you can make a good movie out of just about anything, regardless of who made it.

Also, the "It's just a kids movie" is just the laziest excuse ever. I personally think that children deserve good movies too, and not just a distraction to gawk and laugh at. The movies I mentioned above can actually be enjoyable for people other than 5 year old's. And no, lovely animation and a 'good message' isn't enough anymore.

I will say a few positives, like the animation is amazing, a few jokes got a guilty smile out of me, and I admire Jailbreak's line: "How can you be number one, if there are no other numbers?" So, one or two things to enjoy, but just skip it, and show your kids a better movie.

review_title: Don't be fooled, this "movie" is terrible
review_detailed_main:
"It's just a kids film, you don't have to be to harsh on it" An average excuse from people who don't understand the power of animation. A medium that let's your imagination fly with emotional and powerful movies, with great messages and great different styles, and what did Sony Pictures Animation offered to us? An 88-minute evil, stupid, manipulative and offensive commercial. Yes, it's a commercial, not a movie. Because the film is so focused to promote apps and emojis instead of thinking how to make this movie work.

People might be overrating the Lego movies, but it's justified. As much as it's an excuse to sell Legos, it had an actual creative team that thought a good script first, and then how to sell it. Same case with Toy Story, they had a creative and inspired team that loved animation and cared about this concept as silly it sounds, and it worked.

The emoji movie doesn't want to be creative, funny or at least unique in any aspect. It's your typical "be yourself" movie but with characters that are mean spirited with no personality, with a story that makes no sense and with really bad morals about treating the rest of people.

This is a "movie" that embraces the smartphones and apps and tells you that you should depend on your phone instead of talk with real people and live the real life.

This is a "movie" that manipulates you with pop songs, random and stupid jokes, bad animation and awful dialogue to buy everything they offer in this commercial and to make you think that the things they say in this movie is "profund".

This is a "movie" that says that it's OK to be yourself, but you need to break rules and do nothing to fix your problem unless it's buying a smartphone.

This is a "movie" that it's already dated by the time to review is posted, that shows no compassion to the kids, that treats the audience like stupid people who went to see this and insults every piece of minimum of cleverness just to the sake to sell toys about emojis.

Sony Pictures Animation failed so bad to make this movie a franchise and it shows they don't know how to make a good animated movie, because they are more focused on how to market this towards children.

It's a waste of time and no other kid should see this by its own merits ever again. It needs to be banished from the history of film making and from the art of animation.

You want to show something for your kids? Let them watch anything else instead of Emoji movie. Because it doesn't teach anything good, it's mean spirited, it's too stupid to be taken seriously and it's too annoying and uninspired to be a comedy.

Don't watch it ironically, don't watch it for the memes, don't watch it as a family film, just avoid everything that it's related with this horrible product. Trust me, you'll regret if you see it.

I've warned you.

review_title: It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great: a review by a 5-year old
The example for "I've Seen Worse, much much MUCH worse!"
review_detailed_main:
Ever wonder what would happen if somebody made a movie in which every cliché ever was used with nothing original being added? No? Well what if I told you there was a movie that made Jaws 4: The Revenge look like Alien or made the Room look like The Godfather?

That movie isn't even on par with the awful disgrace to humanity that is the Emoji movie. This is not even close to being a good movie. If you can even call it a movie, it's the worst movie ever made! And there have been lots of bad animated films, hell lots of films in general, what is this the year 2017. But I think this one takes the awful cake made out of rotten eggs made out of smartphone emoji's.

It's a rip off of The Lego Movie, Inside Out, and Wreck it Ralph all at once, and it is beyond any doubt the worst thing that Sony ever created. Worse than Hotel Transylvania, worse than Open Season, worse than the Smurfs reboot, worse than the Annie remake, worse than Battlefield Los Angeles, worse than After Earth, worse than Pixels, worse than Ghostbusters 2016.

There may be films that are worse in plot like Home on the Range, worse aesthetically like Shark Tale, or worse character wise like Norm of the North. But in terms of overall quality, this is the all time low! Stay away! Stay away as far as possible!

THE ABSOLUTE ONLY THING THIS MOVIE CAN DO IS MAKE YOU APPRECIATE OTHER MEDIA! If you disregard my previous advice and watch this film anyway, and somehow manage to sit through it, don't expect a gold medal. You just wasted your time, and I feel bad for you. Likewise if you got this warning too late, once again you have my condolences, especially if you're on the younger side. BUT, you will be able to actively appreciate other media. You'll look at Jurassic World the way you see King Kong, you'll see Sword Art Online the way you see The Last Airbender (the TV series), and you'll see Brave the way you see Toy Story! Go watch any of those before you see this movie, but if you ignore my advice, whenever you watch another form of media at least you'll be able to say without a doubt, "I've seen a lot worse."

(and hey yess Inside out has a trash dump too, and in Wreck it Ralph they also changing between apps)

The book of life plays partially in the "world of the remembered" and Coco does too, that does not mean Coco is any less of a great movie.

Don´t get me wrong! Of course the Emoji Movie is NOT Coco. But to my opinion its a solid 5 or even a weak 6.

Justice League 6.9 Avengers 8.1 The Flash 8.0 Spider-Man 7.3 The Amazing Spider-Man 7.0 Spider-Man Homecoming 7.5

..and yes rotten tomatoes also slaughtered the movie, but we found more and more to not look at their critics because what we consider to be good movies seems to be quite different to their judgement. (e.g. Pixars "Brave" or "the golden compass" that we all here considered to be great movies)

review_title: Before you see the movie, read this...
review_detailed_main:
Overall I believe the movie creatively summed up the moral of "be yourself". This is an important lesson and was portrayed throughout. This is evident in the trailer so this is not a spoiler.

I thought it was OK. The animation was quite good and there was some relatable and creative moments which I think was the only thing this movie had going for it. There was also some cheeky product placement which was very obvious however there were some funny relatable smart phone moments (not going into too much detail) that did make me chuckle... NOT laugh. (big difference).

This movie is basically your cliché animated kids movie.. it has some humor that is slightly funny, a villain, and an end goal. I predicted the ending within the first 10 minutes of watching the film. I was right.

There were so many opportunites missed with this film but I am surprised at the 1.5 average rating. I would have given it a bit more then that.

Overall I do not recommend this movie and rather suggest you spend your money on one of the better movies out right now. cough cough (Dunkirk)

review_title: Pound Shop Lego Movie but it really doesn't suck that hard.
review_detailed_main:
Everyone keeps saying this movie is terrible but it's not that bad.

I think anyone will admit that it's not exactly polished; a lot of the jokes are too in-your-face, there's an over abundance of puns and a lot of the dialogue is heavy and awkward but that doesn't mean it isn't fun.

The inspiration apparently came from toy story and continues a tradition of compiling real pop culture references that we saw in Roger Rabbit, Food Fight and Wreck It Ralph though the movies actual narrative seems most indebted to the Lego movie with its themes of conformism and creativity of expression.

I like the message even if it is kind of ham fisted, both our protagonist Gene and the female lead Jailbreak are likeable even if JailBreak is blatantly just Wyldestyle from the Lego Movie and James Cordon's High comic relief as High Five is maybe kind of annoying but that's more due to lame jokes than any intrinsic problem. I found the antagonist actually pretty creepy, as are all perpetually happy people.

Ultimately I came away feeling warmly about the movie for it's rich, distinctive world, positive message and how it embodies an aspect of its time while tying it to a universal them even if it's not exactly subtle about it.

review_title: Lack of emotion in a film about emotions
review_detailed_main:
The Emoji Movie is one of the most hated films in modern cinema. And boy, I can totally see why. I'm not saying this is the absolute worst movie I've ever seen (oh believe me, I have seen WAY WORSE), but this is still a horrible animated film.

The writing is absolutely awful. It's like they didn't even TRY to put any sort of effort in the script. It's an obvious ripoff of 3 animated films MUCH better than this film: Wreck-It Ralph, The LEGO Movie and Inside Out. The characters are unlikable and very mean-spirited, while others are just dull and forgettable.

The visuals were okay, but other than that The Emoji movie is a heap of unoriginality, and is just plain awful. Do not watch this movie. All those little criticisms you've been hearing about this film are correct. Avoid at all costs!

A good animated movie that kids would love and I laughed at the jokes.

Watched this with my 8 year old daughter and really enjoyed it. Was shocked to see that it had a 3.3 rating. Gave it a 10 in order to offset that horrible rating because it deserves better. The movie concept was unique and had an interesting perspective. Just like Toy Story brought our toys to life, this movie brings your apps/emojis to life, and I thought the concept was executed really well. There were also some good lines in the script. Deserves 10 stars!

While the idea of an emoji movie is pretty silly, the introduction with the introduction of the characters is still interesting. Associating a lot of images with something that is nothing more than a series of jokes requires a certain intelligence and ingenuity. A emoji with greater capacity than the rest must face the challenge of discovering himself while joining other emojis that have certain interests. Finally, an evil corporation that directs the destiny of emojis is challenged to put control of the situation lest something finally get out of control. There are references to multiple applications and programs which would charm someone born in this century. There are a couple of great moments (dancing is one of them) and the movie, whether the perfectionists like it or not, isn't that bad.

review_title: I would rate this movie -10 if i could
review_detailed_main: There's just one word to describe this movie HORRIBLE Emoji sucks more than rotten fish

I finally watched this solely because of the bad reviews and because it's on Netflix and I don't understand what's so bad about it.

It wasn't a great movie, but really wasn't that bad. It had an actual plot, a decent enough script, and there was character growth. I'd rank it significantly higher than the 2024 animated disasters Despicable Me 4 and The Garfield Movie(both which were unwatchable). The Emoji Movie had its cringe moments, especially when out-of-touch Hollywood decided again to play 80s music for children, but overall was an okay movie.

My main issue is that they targetted the wrong audience. Children aren't really texting, and there would've just been more opportunity if they had made this an adult cartoon. Emojis are used a lot on dating apps and texting apps, but not so much on Spotify and Just Dance.

Being a person who's outer expression is mostly 'meh', I will now be reminded of this movie whenever I'm aware of my outward indifference. So now I feel like I've been forever tainted.

Most people have slammed this as the worst thing to ever be made. That's harsh, even though I don't completely disagree. But I have seen worse things. Still, why 2 stars and not 1 or less? Well, 1 is for the voicing talent of T.J. Miller. I like the guy. He's what made the Silicon Valley series funny. And here, just hearing his voice, felt comforting. He's like that friend with the cool voice and the interesting stories (true or not) who can talk forever non-stop, but you don't mind because they fill up a void with life. They entertain when you can't be bothered to make an effort. The life of the party when you're happy to take a backseat and just chill whilst nursing your drink. He makes a good buddy.

The other 1 star just has to go to the sheer audacity of making a movie about emojis in the first place. What would Disney and Pixar writers from 20 years ago make of this? Even the writers of the dystopian Wall-E (2008) would have not predicted the dystopian direction of something like The Emoji Movie becoming a reality. Still, the pitch to Sony (or Columbia Pictures) would have been easy enough. 'Emojis come in a variety of expressions,' they would say. 'So many of them. And each of them can be a different character. Then there's all the animals. And body parts. And objects. And... all the other things you can send in a text that isn't a letter. All of those are characters, so the world building is easy peasy. At this point, Sony (or Columbia Pictures) are almost on board. 'But what about the story?' they'd say. Well, for the producers, that would be the easiest part. Just take a bit of Inside Out (the behind-the-scenes universe) and a bit of Wreck-it-Ralph adventure, and there you have it. The same old rehashed story told from another perspective. They'd argue that kids and young teens would gobble it up. Seeing their favorite emojis up on the screen would be a thing they never knew they loved, up until that moment. 'Just think of all the stuffed and plastic emoji toys that could follow after the movie's success,' they'd say.

It was a gutsy move. Especially that it was a move made by grown-up responsible adults. Serious people talked about this in conference meetings and studio discussions and writer/animator sessions.

Maybe the whole thing was a dare between the producers and creators? See if they could get something like this green-lit? Because that type of boldness deserves some form of respect, surely. (Nevertheless, Netflix would have happily payed for it anyway if Sony had said no. But Netflix is hardly a challenge in getting something through, so they wouldn't count).

If you want to see an amazing crime-drama, "The Emoji Movie" is for you. It contains a dazzling story, a insanely beautiful musical score, and well developed characters. I'd reccomend this movie if you like The Godfather and it's sequels. Though when you compare the Godfather and Emoji Movie, the God Father almost seems like a shameless rip off, yet it came first. I would show it to my kids if I had some.

I had very low expectations about this movie due to its extremely low rating, but it's actually not so bad. I've seen a lot of worse animated pictures and I'm clueless about why the rating is so low. I'm also unsure, however, why there are so many user reviews rating it 10. It's an average children's animated movie which adults can also vaguely enjoy.

review_title: No laughter. No fun. No hope.
review_detailed_main:
I got forced to watch this one. I never wanted to- there was a small child relation who wanted to see a movie and this was the only one on in theaters when we were out. And by gum, was it bad.

So, so bad.

Bad enough it took me nearly three months just to work up the courage to write a quick review.

The characters/actors... it was downright depressing hearing Sir Patrick Stewart, one of the finest actors alive, voicing a character named... Poop. Ugh. But generally, the characters were awful. The female lead, I wanted to fling her out a window. She's loathsome. The comedic sidekick was only made worse by James Corden's poor performance. And Eugene, the main lead, was just irritating and unappealing.

The comedy is dreadful. The plot, frightful. The little girl I went with fidgeted the whole time; not once did she laugh or smile. She seemed bored. So don't try and claim 'kids will like it'. Kids are too good for this.

This is an ad. A poorly done ad. Avoid it- you can't even MST3K this thing. Abandon all hope, ye who view.
